text: On tap at brewery. Pours very black with tan head. Nose and taste are chocolate, coffee and tangy cranberry. Not my thing.

Dark brown pour with a kaki head. Dark roasted malt aromas. I mostly get the bitter dark roasted malts. There are hints of cranberry but its more like cranberry juice as opposed to cranberries. It does add a unusual tartness to the beer. Average body and mouthfeel.

Tap at Surly. Dark black. Really dark. Great lacing for mini glass. Aroma is kinda weak cranberry, stouty. Taste is more of the same. Actually pretty good but lacks a ton of the cranberry of old rakes.
St Pattys brew on tap at Surly. Good and interesting cranberry stout. Would drink again.
Draft at the source. Opaque maroon, tan head. Aroma has cocoa powder, coffee, cranberry. Taste starts with sweet chocolate then tart fruity berries, licorice. Delicious.
On tap at Surly. Dark brown pour. Slightly fruity malt and chocolate aroma. Taste is more bitter chocolate and smokey wood. Wish there was more cranberry in the taste but still good.

On tap at the Surly Beer Hall - a special rebrew for their tenth anniversary coming up. Dark brown pour with a slight off white head and lacing. Malty nose with some fruit notes. Tart, malty, finishing slightly acidic with a dose of bitter chocolate. Cool combination. Apparently half the cranberries used in this version? Also 9.4% ABV.

Keg @ Surly. Deep brown pour with a small head. Nose is of toasted malts. A bit of coffee and dark chocolate. Hints of red
Fruit skin. Flavor is moderately bitter. Tangy dark fruit on the finish. Peppery hood. A bit boozy. Full body, soft carbonation.

On tap at surly pours a dark brown/black with amber highlights and a large ran head. Chalky fruity aroma, like an Easter jelly bean, molasses, caramel, and dry chocolate malts. Taste of bakers chocolate, sharp tart juicy cranberry rolls nicely into light oak and a bitter hoppy finish. Cranberry becomes more evident as it warms. Very nice, I prefer it warmed a little.
Bottle from Bryce, Dark brown, red hues, tiny white head. Aromas of cranberry, malt, chocolate. Taste similar, sweet, booze finish. Not bad for the age.

June 23, 2013 - bottle shared by Bryce. Dark pour with nice head and lacing. Aroma was cranberry and malt. Taste was much better than expected. Nice slightly tart cranberry, malt and splash of alcohol. Nice smooth and medium to full body. Huge thanks to Bryce for hooking me up with a beer I did not think I would have a chance to try!

On tap at GTMW 2012.  Hazy brown with a thin tan head.  Aroma is mildly sour and fruity with cranberry and dark malts with a bit of chocolate in the background.  Taste of chocolate, cranberries, tannins and roasted malts.  Semi-sour.

18th July 2009Opaque black stout. Soft palate. Very tangy, flirting with sour. Dark chocolate malt offset by the sourish cranberry. These two flavours dominate and make for an interesting if not entirely harmonious brew.

Bottle with friends, courtesy of forgetfu. Big thanks, Bill! Hazy, dark brown appearance with a small tan head. Vinous, cran-raspberry, roasty anise aroma. Fairly tart cranberry, tangy berry, roasty malty flavor that is fairly sour and fruit forward. Im surprised that the fruit is still so prevalent.

Bottle pour at Bills tasting #293, big, big thanks to Bill for sharing this one.  Blackish red pour with thin to no off white head, nice looking but no lacing.  Aroma brought notes of big sweet and tart cranberries, some slight sweet chocolate, toffee, vanilla notes, hints of molasses.  Taste is big, big tart cranberry, the sweetness went away right away into a slightly thin caramel, chocolate note, hints of vanilla, touch of dusty cocoa as well.  Tart finish for sure, interesting brew!

750 ml bottle poured a clear reddish brown with a lingering ring of tasn foam. Aromas of roastiness, cranberry and dark chocolate. Palate was light to medium bodied and crisp. Flavors of cranberry, roastiness and light dark chocolate with a crisp dry lingering cranberry finish.

GTMW.  Brown-black, big beige head.  Fruity cocoa aroma.  Wow.  An interesting mix of flavors for sure.  Tart, holds up quite well.  Sour and lactic, with a nice chocolate smoothness.  Well done, intense.
Sampled this at ABR this fall.  A very nice fruit beer, not the best Ive had. but very nice indeed!

750 ml bottle shared by Dansting, Dan has been holding on to it for a little while to share with me, I highly appreciate it.  Its about 3.5 years old.  Its rare to come across a beer with cranberry that isnt a cheap as wheat.  Pours black with no head.  Aroma has a weird fruitiness, apparently cranberries but I wouldnt have guessed.   Its a very strong, fumy, and bitter smelling stout. Flavor is bitter on the black patent malts I would say.  Flavor just comes off as a strong stout and there is an non-distinct berriness, I would not call it cranberry.  I wonder how they crushed the cranberries, may have made a big difference.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: 750 ml bottle shared by Dansting.  Pour is a darker brown with a thin light tan head.  Aroma is roasted smoked malt with a nice clean fruit cranberry shining through.  After the darker malts and tart cranberry clear a bit, the wood starts to shine through a bit with oakiness.  The taste is the nose, with a nice balance between the dark roasted malt and the tart cranberry fruit.  As it warms, the cranberry really comes to the front, which is pretty amazing given the age on this beer.  Palate is medium to full bodied, active carbonation and the finish dries out with barrel woodiness.  Interesting beer, glad I got a chance to try this one - thanks a bunch Dan!

Bomber shared by Dansting. Pours a dark brown with a thin tan head. The nose is a tart fruitiness over roasty dark malt. Medium-bodied and quite tart with a drying finish. Tart, tart cranberry sits atop a solid roasty stout. This is interesting stuff, but even after this much time, the cranberry dominates. Thanks for sharing this rarity with us Dan.

On tap at GTMW - Cola pour with a ring of tan head. Nose is mostly smoked malt. Real light, with a dark pumpernickel bread base. Taste is the same, but with a touch of cranberry and some lightly soured malt. Dark and dry finish. Seems a bit limp, but thats to be expected. I did like that there was a bit of tartness left. Well carbonated and smooth. Would have liked to try this a couple years ago.

On tap at the GTMW 2011.  How bad ass is that?  A beer Ive longed to try since my first days at rate beer.   Pours a dark brown with a brown head.  Aroma of cranberries, sweet malt, oxidation.  Some maple syrup, mild oatmeal cookies.  Very obvious oak barrel notes.  Pretty awesome flavor with mild tartness from the cranberries with the cookie sweetness of the malt.  Oxidation is also present, albeit mild.  Full bodied, an absolute pleasure to drink.  So glad I got to try this one.

Pours an opaque dark brown with an off-white head. Sour and extraordinarily bitter. Tart with aromas of berries and lots of oak. Full bodied. Medium carbonation. Tart, bitter finish with more oak (too much).

Sampled from the tap at the 2010 GTMW. Poured black with a dark brown head that lasted throughout the beer. Aroma was nice with a combination of roasted dark malts and quite tart cranberries. Flavor began with dark grains and roasted malt the melded beautifully with the growing tart cranberry flavor.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2010 Tap. Got to try this beer at Great Taste of the Midwest this past weekend. What a treat. This beer poured a maroon reddish black color with a slight head. Surpirisingly the aroma was still very much of cranberries along with the traditional IS notes of dark roast. The taste is well balanced between the cranberry and dark stout flavors. No hop presence to speak of really. Medium mouthfeel. Not sure why but at this point I thought this beer would have gone down hill, not the case at all. Still very good and delicious. Do yourself a favor and never pass up a chance to try this beer.

Bottle, 75cl, from trade with Akevitt. A dark brown beer topped by a dark beige head. Vinous, berryish nose with cocoa and roasted malts. Very smooth, if one can use that word when talking aroma. Slightly roasted flavor, with berries and hints of cocoa, quite vinous, but not much alcohol warming. Full-bodied. Some berry-like sourness finishes the whole thing. A lovely beer! Smooth, vinous and slightly sourish, all very well balanced. 091113

Poured a hazy brown color with a thin off-white head.  The aroma was on the tart side with a soy component and some woody notes.  Overall vinous in the nose.  Tart vinous flavor.  Mildly bitter on the finish.  Medium bodied.  I wrote #168 so I am guessing this was the bottle number.

(Sample Date: 7/18/2009   Source:Other)   Bottle courtesy of Immy. Big raisin aroma with sweet maltiness. Cloudy dark brown with small tan head. Sour very roasty with raisin and slightly astringent roastiness. Chocolate and coffee. Finish is dry and tart with a hint of woodiness.

0.75 L bottle, kindly shared by yngwie.  A coarse, yellowish, foamy head upon a very dark, mahogny colored body.  Dry, vinous aroma. A prominent smell of berries up front. Fresh, natural, with a rounded tartness. Chocolate notes and a mild coffee in the background. Suggestions of wood and cellar. Taste is complex and balanced. A rich cranberry flavor, dry, tart and fresh, blends well in with the lightly toasted, chocolatey malts. Coffee notes and a touch of vanilla and wood. Well-bodied. A pleasant astringency on the palate. Dry, vinous, berry-fruity finish. A lovely fruit beer!

Shared bottle that cellared quite well. Poured black/brown with ruby tones showing through, and a bubbly head that diminished so quickly that  it was hard to get a read on the color. I guess somewhat off white/light tan, leaving a very small ring, light film, and some spots of lacing. The aroma was tart dark fruit and a touch of vinous nature. The flavor was tart cranberries, only a hint of sweetness, dark chocolate, some moderate hop bitterness and a dry, slightly tannic finish. The alcohol didnt seem to show up.  As I said when this first came out for Surlys 2nd anniversary. A big fruit, novelty brew, that was enjoyable trying once. But in this case, twice, and better than a year and a half later.

(Bottle, thanks Guerde and OSLO!) Pours dark brown to black with a light brown head. The aroma is of sour cranberries with (chocolate/dark bread) roasted malt in the background. Undertones of raspberry vinegar, honey, vanilla covered green apples, mouldy basement, wood, coconut and butter. The flavour is light sweet, light bitter and medium acidic with notes of tart cranberries, roast, wood, vanilla, butter, vinegar and hints of fruits. The mouthfeel is astringent and tart. Dry finish. Medium bodied. More interesting than fantastic. Still one of the best fruit-flavour stouts I have tried.

Sampled at the 09 RBPTE, courtesy of treyrab. Light fruity hops with cherry aromas, cranberry and mint?, a bit of oxidation and mild malt sweetness. Dark brown-ruby murky body with spare light brown head. Medium body with lively carbonation and a chalky astringent after. Fairly tart with good acidity and only light sweetness and bitterness. An interesting beer.
Bottle courtesy of Immy at Immys Backyard Throwdown. Pours brown in color with brown head. Aroma roasted malt, coffee and fruit. Taste sweet, chocolate and fruity with bitter finish.

Dark brown with a big tan head. Big old fruity aroma. Cranberries are there, of course, chocolaty and full of dark malt. Sweet, cranberry, big. Im not sure what I should think of this, its not really imperial stout-ish, but I dont know how else to really think of the flavor combination.

Sample at the 8/9 Pgh tasting, thanks to Treyrab!  Smell is big and volatile. Dark with a big foamy head. Big heavy alky beer taste impressions. Cranberries in there fer sure. Comes across like an impy stout with fruit in there. Some creamy carbonation in ther. Has many of the attributes that I find in wine. Thanks trey!
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Sample at the 8/9 Pgh tasting, thanks to Treyrab!Dark brown with a small tan head. Nose shows significant malt depth, the heavy cranberry and imperial stout chocolate balanced nicely. The flavor is even more impressive, and though quite sweet, the incredible malt depth is never lost behind the sweet fruit and chocolate notes because the cranberry imparts a soft tart balance. Decadent stuff and among my favorites of the day.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2009 Sampled from a 750 ml brown bottle this beer poured a black-brown color with a trace of a tan head. The aroma was tart, tangy, sweet and malty with noted cranberry. The flavor was tart and bitter with a strong cranberry presence and a light, sweet and malty undertones. The finish was long, bitter, tart and had lingering cranberry. Fairly thick in body. Nice.

Had this one at the RB Pittsburgh tasting.  One two punch with FFFs Apocalypse Cow in the "this shouldnt work this well" category.  Good looking beer, nice black liquid with eggshell-ish head.  Aroma was a bit of an odd mix that had me worried.  Im a chocolate purist however.  Flavor works much better than I thought it would, and may even get me to try a chocolate covered cranberry..one of these days.

Wow, I cant believe I got to try this. This one poured a nice black color with a light tan head. Aroma was thick dark chocolate and sour tart cranberries... great contrast. Flavor was nice roasted malts, dark chocolate, finished with a naturla sweet and sour mix of fresh cranberries. This is some majorly complex stuff.

Bottle courtesy of Immy on 07/18/2009. Dark brown body with a medium creamy tan head. Sweet roasty and chocolate aroma with fruity notes. Sweet chocolate and roast flavor, with some fruity cranberry notes. Medium full body with mdoerate carbonation.

Bottle shared at Johns gathering. Poured a mahogany with a light tan head. Aroma is sweet dark fruits mixed with some roasty coffee. Flavor is surprisingly acidic following the aroma (though not so much considering the addition of cranberries) with some flavors of light chocolate acidic fruit dominating. Overall some nice flavors but I was not really crazy for the acidity clashing from the sweeter roastier flavors that would otherwise have comprised the the bulk of the flavor profile if it had not been for the cranberries.

Sample from a bottle shared by DalzAle @ DLD 09.  Pours brown with a small beige head.  The aroma had some roasted malt, but was more tart fruity than anything.  The flavor was tart cranberry, moderately sweet, roast, and a bit acidic.  The finsh was dry and tart.  Medium bodied and was a nice surprise to sample.

Bottle courtesy of Immy at Immys Backyard Throwdown. This has 072 written on it from a paint pen. Not sure of the significance. Dark brown to near black pour. Opaque. Short tan head. Aroma is roasted malts, fruit, and light coffee. Taste is strong tart fruits (I found out after tasting this it was cranberry based), roasted malts, berry notes and chocolate covered cherries. Body tart, medium and slightly chewy with dense carbonation. Ends with more tart fruits, roasted malt, chocolate and berries. Nice!
Bottle thanks to Cletus for sharing.  Pours a mahogany body with an of white head.  Sweet honey nectar, coffee and a berry tartness, chewy and slightly tart.  Nice brew.

Courtesy of Immy at Immys Backyard Throwdown (a BIG thanks to Immy for sharing this one).  Very dark red pour.  Aroma of chocolate and cranberries.  Flavor is of coffee, dark chocolate, and tart cherries (I know they are cranberries but tart cherry is what comes through).  This is an incredible beer.  I tried it once at GABF in 2008 but I jumped at a second chance.  Many thanks to Immy.
@ Immy Backyard Throwdown. Pours a dark brown. Smell was a dark chocolate cherry. Awesome. Had a sweet taste of chocolate and fruit. Overall a great beer. I would have again.
UPDATED: AUG 5, 2009 Pours dark brown with a sparse amount od carbonation.  Smells of coffee, oaky, cranberries.  Tastes of cranberries, oak, dry with a spicy finish.

Shared by Immy at Immys Backyard Throwdown. Thanks! Pours a murky orange color with a medium head. Decent head retention and lacing. Aroma of toffee, caramel and cherries. Taste is tart cherries, cocoa, toffee, cranberry and something milky. Lightly bitter and lightly tart. Full bodied.
@ Immy Backyard Throwdown.  Caramely on the nose.  Cherry and cranberry on the palate with a little tartness.  Very very good.

Tap at ACBF. It is beyond me how this beer wound up with such high ratings. Incredibly boozy and the tartness and acidity from the cranberry created a beer that tasted practically infected. Poorly, poorly integrated components, memorable in a bad way.

On draft at ACBF09.  Pours brown with a tan head.  Aroma of bourbon or some type of liquor and also maybe putrid vomit.  Yeah, this smelled pretty bad.  Flavor of very sweet malt and roasted notes with a tart, lactic finish.  This was very odd and very bad.  People liked this???
4/4/5/3/11 (2.7/5)
ACBF09.  Did not enjoy this.  Fruit notes in the aroma, wouldnt say theyre cranberry.  Flavor is of cheap cranberry juice with cheap vodka.  Reminded me of college.
Another old rating. Pours a black color with some red notes to it. Aroma was of chocolate and a light tartness on the nose. Flavor was pretty good and had some cranberry notes coming through.

750mL Bottle. #264. Weird paste and glue aroma, with a bit of half-rotten bog cranberries. Theres a dusting of chocolate and some alcohol. Slightly garbagey and old smelling. A touch of solvent. Pours a clearish black-brown, with a foamy head in creamy tan. Flavor has a brisk charred roast that marries with a touch of jellied cranberry sauce and some orange peel. The stout base seems a little thin. Theres a palpable dusty hop presence and some light plant stems. Alcohol well underlaid, with this tasting more like 6%. As a fruit beer, this is a pretty good stout. Honestly, this is probably a decent stout, but the fruit is just not a presence. Otherwise, its good work with malts.

4/25/2009:  Surly Two is dark brown color is some sort of fruit that is not apparent at first in the aroma.  The flavor is dry, sweet, and tart with a hint of roast.  The fruit the becomes obvisous - CRANBERRY!  This is a very good and very balanced beer.
Sample from bottle at Dark Lord Day 2009.  Rating #95 for this beer.
Bottle at DLD 09 ... black ... thin lacing ... sweet roast malt nose ... little sourness ...little coffee ... dark fruits

dalzale hooks me up wtih my #1 wanted beer with a nice big sample at DLD. YESSSS!  Nice brown pour.  Chocolate, toffee, cranberry, coffee and some toffee.  Flavor is really nice.  Full bodied, nice chocolate notes and the cranberries are noticeable but in a sour way.  Damn its good. Thanks again my friend!

Pours brown with some reddish hues.  The aroma had plenty of chocolate and roasted type malts with an underlying cranberry tartness.  The flavor really let the fruit shine though.  This was one of the most interesting beers of the day for me.

Bottle shared graciously by DalzAle at DLD 09 (Munster, IN). Woot! Pours a dark brownish opaque pour with some ruby notes around the edges. Light brownish head that clings to the sides of the glass. Aromas push some darker malts, well covered by tart cranberries and their sweetness and light bitterness. Body throws darker malts, some roast and coffee with more subtle chocolate. The cranberries steal the show for me, with dark fruit elements and that telltale tartness. Tart takes over the roast, and really bumps this beer beyond for me. Fantastic!

Bottle at a Club-Tasting (THX to Me). Black - offwhite head. Cherry, berries, cranberries, wood, oakey notes, chocolate, nutty notes, caramel, tart, nice bitterness, light coffee, dried fruits. Lovely thick light oily body. Very nice.
Flaske, drukket sammen med klubben. Sort med et tæt moccafarvet skum. Dufter af tranebær, chokolade, rister malt og sød tobak. Smager af tranebær, træ, frugter. Er dejlig bitter, tyk og olieret.
Bottle thx to you. Almost pitch black with a small head. Quite well balanced and interesting. Notes of carnberries, chocolate, coffee, fruit, malt, dried fruit and hops.

Darker brown color with a roasty aroma that has some nice cranberry and chocolate to it.  Flavor is rather stouty with some roast, chocolate, and lighter cranberries. Nice feel.  Not quite like a New Glarus Cherry Stout or other fruit stouts, but its tasty.

Bottle generously shared by Yonkers 65. 86th rate of this beer. Beer pours dark brown with some red hues and no head. The aroma is an intriguing mix of dark roasted malts and some tart earthy cranberries. Initially sweet dark malts are followed by a good dose of roasted malts with a cranberry tartness that rounds it out. Not mindblowingly tart, but tart in a way that it created an interesting dryness when combined with the roasted malt notes that are in the finish. I really liked this.

Bottled #362. A hazy deep red beer with a thin lazing brown head. The aroma is sweet malty with notes of fresh fruit, cranberries, wood, roasted malt, and over ripe fruit. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of dusty hops, over ripe fruits as well as lighter notes of cranberries, alcohol, and chocolate. There is a slight tartness in the finish. Thanks Shaun for sharing.

Rating #1000! Bottle #241 via and shared with oakbluff. Near black in colour with moderate carbonation. Aromas are of tar, leafy cranberry, and charred roasted malts. Flavors are of mild vienna roast coffee, pronounced cranberry, and chocolate. Areally  interesting mouthfeel is created by the blend of roasted malts and tart cranberry. Quite a bizzare beer, but one I really enjoyed.
Sampled at Winterfest 08. Pours dark with a tan head with mild carbonation. Red fruit cherries and chocolate scent that carries through to the taste with a bit of tartness at the finish.

Poured a lightly hazy, dark mahogany color with a small, tan head that left light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, toast, and cranberries.  Taste of roast, vanilla, caramel malts, and light cocoa, with a tart berry note in the finish.  Did we figure out there were about 400 bottled on this one?

Big thanks to footbalm for answering my call out for this one. 750ml bottle marked on the back 163. Poured a dark black color with an averaged sized off white head. There was also a reddish tint to it. Aromas of chocolate, caramel, lighter cranberries, roast, and cherries. Tastes of chocolate, the same light cranberries, vanilla, and roast. Lighter sweet start with a light tart finish. Alcohol content well hidden. A very drinkable and refreshing beer.

Much thanks to hopdog for sharing this one.  Great label and the wax was a nice touch. Pours a deep black with a medium bubbly/creamy tan head that left lacing.  Aroma of chocolate, toffee, caramel, light cranberry notes, floral, some alcohol and vanilla. Flavor of chocolate, lightly roasted malt, vanilla, caramel, cranberry (more so in flavor than aroma) and lightly tart notes.

22 oz bottle shared at miketds tasting

Thanks to whomever brought this out.  Intriguing due to the cranberry aspect this one could be a stand out on a normal night.  If you are lucky enough to have one be nice and share.  Im sure you can make lots of friends that way.

Aroma / Appearance - Creamy sheets of lacing and no head gave this brownish black beer a nice texture.  Fruity with black coffee and malts in the forefront it makes itself known.

Flavor / Palate - Cranberry bread, coffee, and dark chocolate create a smooth experience.  The fruity finish sets it apart by providing a nice wrapping to a solid beer.  Hopefully this makes it to the GTMW in some form this fall.

Bottle pours black with a very thin tan head.  Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, and some cranberry and cherry.  Flavor is vanilla, chocolate malt, with a tart cranberry cherry finish.  This was a nice brew.  I liked it.
TAP: at the Muddy Pig (St. Paul, MN). Pours dark brown/black. Aroma and taste are tart cranberry, roasted malts. A little bit of dry hop bitter at the back end. Great beer.

Bottle #139.  Pour was almost black with the barely noticeable hint of red and a little bit of carbonation.  Aroma of mellow bourboned cranberries and rich sweet malts.  Flavor of toasted malts, vanilla, very smooth bourbon and tart cranberry all the way through.  Im very sad they wont be making this again, as it tastes much better aged than it did when I had a chance to try it on tap a year ago.
22 oz bottle shared.  Dark pour with decent head.  Aromas of fruit and berries.  Flavor was much tarter than the aroma.  More cranberries and some other tart fruit as well.  Pretty darn tasty

750mL bottle #165, courtesy of MeLikeBeer, poured into a snifter.

Pours a dark brown with ruby hints out of the bottle and settles in as an opaque black in the glass. The tan head is huge and shows great retention and leaves sheets of lacing.

The aroma has lots of tart cranberries with a strong balance of dark roasted malts and some sweet dark fruit. There is also some chocolate and a bit of wood as well.

The taste didn’t quite live up to the aroma for me. The tart cranberries didn’t meld with the malts and chocolate as well as the aroma suggested. It starts with a slightly bitter/sour berry taste that gives way to a toasted malt backbone. The finish has tons of the sour berries in it.

The mouthfeel is smooth but probably a little thin for me. It’s a bit dry as well.

This is one interesting beer from the folks at Surly but the taste just doesn’t quite come together for me. Nonetheless, big thanks to Brent for sharing this rare bottle.

Sampled GABF 2008
Quite a dark, concentrated amber-brown color that is topped by a tan’ish frothy head.  This is very strongly aromatic, with lots of Bourbon-like notes (vanillin, coconut, a hint of butterscotch and some light spicy oak that kicks in towards the finish along with some nose burning alcohol).  There is a touch of non-descript fruit character underneath the strong barrel aromatics; definitely a bit too dominated by the barrel character though.

This beer is lightly tart somehow and not nearly as sweet or rich as I was expecting.  There is a spicy oak and alcohol burn that is fairly evident in the finish and is more dominant than the other barrel-like notes that I noticed in the aroma; there is a touch of butterscotch here though.  The beer is actually quite astringent, with a quite noticeable tannic quality to it in the finish.  The body is a touch thinner than I was expecting, though it certainly makes it more drinkable.  The noticed tartness adds / accentuates some flavors of tamarind, tart raisin, cranberry and sour prune (this last a product of the tartness and some rich malt notes).

This is not bad, but certainly not quite what I was expecting; the tartness and barrel character seem to mix in odd ways at times and it is missing the malt richness that could carry both notes a bit more.  I had no idea while drinking this beer that it had cranberries in it, but the tartness certainly makes sense now.
GABF 08.  Cool ass brew from the Surly boys...glad to see it was a bit thumped up in the abv dept.  Not overly complex, but enjoyable and another surly winner.

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2008 Sampled at the 2008 Great American Beer Festival. This was a standout for fruit beers at the festival. I really liked the intrigue and creativity put into this beer. Pours a black center with brown edges. Not much carbonation. Sweet brown sugar, cranberry juice and cherries blend well in the aroma. The flavor is sweet and tangy with cranberries, yet manages to stay very balanced with the dark grain bill. Finishes with a lingering sourness. Nice.

Soft but chewy fruit nose with vanilla and toffee hints.  This was a dark colored beer with a thin tan colored head.  The mouth was sour with cranberry, tobacco, and other earthy things going on. I found it a rather fun beer, really...maybe a touch too one dimensional to be fantastic, but fun indeed.

Draught at GABF 2008.
Black coloured with a medium sized beige head.
Sweet and roasted aroma of shisky, berries and vanilla.
Sweet and roasted flavour of whisky, vanilla and cranberries.
Sweet finish.

Bottle, sampled at RBSG 08, with thanks to Toncatcher. Pours a deep dark brown with a tan ring. Aroma of malt and berries, the cranberry comes through wonderfully. Tart and dry toasted malt and cranberry taste. Lingering tartness. Different and very tasty.

GABF 2008.  Pours dark brown with a small, fizzy, off-white head, somewhat diminishing with fair lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (bread, cookie, cereal), light hops (grass), average yeast (earth, musty) with notes of wood and cranberries.  Medium bodied, sticky texture, average carbonation, and a bitter finish.  Average duration, light sweetness, moderate acidity and bitterness.
tap.  Black color. big bubble.  dryish.  tart and tannic.  Malty aroma.  Not as good as I was expecting

At the ABR.  Pours deep dark brown with huge tan head. Strong bourbon oak and vanilla notes, subtle light tart fruits notes. Tart fruits that are cranberries came off a little sweet. Reminds me of a traditional lambic from the way it made my mouth pucker. Notes of bourbon in the finish and a good amount of acidity. Very nice beer.
thanks to bitbucket tasting. Dark brown with small head. Interesting balance of chocolate and red fruit. A little bit tannic towards the finish.

22 oz. bottle @ liquid sunshine tasting - thanks to yonkers65; pours dark brown, murky and flat; thin tan head remains around the edges; thick and creamy; tons of cherries, but much more on the dank side of things rather than the sweet; drinks dry; pretty nice

RBSG 2008. Interesting tart berry nose, once Dennis pointed out the cranberries it all seemed to make sense. I grew up in a place with lots of cranberries, but they don’t use them for much so the mind seems to skip right over them. The impart a bitter and tart character to it, working off the sweeter dark roasty malts. The body seems to thin out a bit from their tartness, but it seemed to come together nicely.

Bottle 389 shared with grimreeser. Pours dark brown with light beige head. Aroma of roast and cranberries. Medium bodied. Nice balanced flavor of dark roast, chocolate. and cranberry. Finish is semi dry  and tart, with lots of lingering cranberry. Interesting and unique. Chad tells me its better on tap.

Pours like mudd or meltd chocolate mix very murky huge rocky tan head.  Big bourbon oak and vanilla notes, mostly barreling in the aroma some light tart fruits come through but only a little here.  Full well coated pal.  Tart fruits that I first thoguht were raspberry from the sweetness but I guess are cranberries.  Reminds me of sour brown after that.  a light vanilla comes through some good oak dryness.  Notes of bourbon in the finish and a good amount of acidity.  Very nice beer.

Bottle sampled at RBSG ’08.  Pours with a dark brown body topped by a medium thick, tan head with a good amount of lacing.  It’s sweet yet slightly tart and fruity with a little underlying funk.  Medium bodied and dry.
22, capped and waxed. Thanks, Yonkers65! Opaque and very dark brown, tan head. Semi-sweet cherry (or actually cranberry) nose. Chocolate-covered cranberry/raisin taste.

Bottle at RBSG grand tasting. Thanks to Toncatcher who brought this. Pours dark brown with a good tan head. The aroma was rich with raisins, berries and roasted malts. The taste is slightly sour with cherries and raspberries. The mouthfeel is full and malty. The finish is long and slightly sour with lingering red fruits. Overall: I almost turned down tasting this one because i thought that I had previously rated it, I’m glad that I tried it. Wow 18 beers sampled so far at RBSG and every one a winner.
Bottle from Toncatcher @ RBSG Grand Tasting.  Pours black with a tan ring.  Nose is tart with cranberries.  Taste is sweet and big and nice overall.

Courtesy of tpd975. Pours deep dark brackish brown with thin tan head. The aroma is roasty dark malts and chocolate blending into notes of cranberries, ripe strawberries and other assorted fruits. Pleasing mild mix of aromas. The taste starts with a quick pulse of dark malts to chocolate malts to thick sticky malt sweetness and turns quickly toward somewhat unripe fruit tartness. This fruit tartness persists and rides all the way to the finish with notes of dark, sweet and chocolate malts showing up from time to time and growing some into the finish.

22, capped and waxed. Thanks, Yonkers65! Black, opaque. Dense tan head. Slightly soured nose. Rich sweet chocolate there, too. Medium body, a little chalky. Sweet and sour together. Mild finish. Good but not exceptionally dimensional or forward.

Bottle sampled @ Columbus tasting:  First off, looking too closely at this label made me feel very weird inside.  Second, so did the cranberries.  This beer is scalded vanilla milk, with the syrupy quality of cranberry.  Our nation’s 12th President - Zachary Taylor - died from eating cherries and milk in the heat, and I don’t really recommend it, either.
user_location: I F&ckin hate those guys from, Ohio, USA

text: thanks for sharing, iowaherkeye. The body is nearly black with a light khaki head. The aroma is like cherry cough syrup with some almonds. There is a strange light milk chocolate note. The taste has some light tart cherries with some milk chocolate. The body is lightly carbonated with some light fruit in the finish.

Courtesy of tpd975. Thanks Greg.
Pours a dark amber/black. Aroma is filled with cranberries and hops. Mouthfeel has hints of chocolate, tart and a little too bitter in my opinion.

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2008 Rating #700. Bottle courtesy tpd975. Thanks Greg for such a rare treat. Pours black with a one finger tan head. Strong aroma of cranberries with a hint of roasted malt. Taste is the same as aroma. Medium mouthfeel with a mild amount of bitterness and a mild to moderate amount of acidity. Alcohol is very well hidden. Not very complex but good.

badbeer supplied a bottle of this bad boy.  Thanks Mike!  early black pour with a small khaki head.  Aroma was cranberry juice,  hops,  caramel,  toffee.  Flavor was tart cran up front,  chocolate,  coffee,  orange citrus.  Slightly sour finish.  almost puckering at first but not bad once you have a sip or two.  Medium carbonation,  long finish.

Black color, with a beige head that had good retention and spotty lacing.  Smell of cranberries, though I don’t know that I would have said cranberries over sour cherries, had I not known cranberries were used.  Smell was also pretty hoppy; which somehow worked well with the rest of the character of this beer.  Taste had tart cranberries, tannins, plums, and just a bit of roast.  Medium bodied and light on the carbonation.  I rather enjoyed this and wish I had another bottle of it.

Bottle shared at Cbus tasting 11. I LIKED IT. Not a huge fan of fruit beers but this one was good. Pour was blackish brown with amber hues. Smell was vanilla and berries. Flavor to me was maple syrup and cranberries. A delightful treat on my tongue. And KUDOS on the artwork. I love it. Very nice bottle work. Probably one of my favorite fruit beers of all time. And hey, since cranberries are good for the urinary tract, I guess I will go have another...

UPDATED: JUN 30, 2008 On draught at the Acadia. March 23rd 
The beer was opaque black with thick creamy brown head. In the aroma there was hops (not obnoxious), roasted malt, and mild cranberry. In the flavor there were Surlys signature hops, tart/sour cranberries, and sweet roasted malt. The beer was smooth with a dry cranberry finish. As it warmed I got more alcohol, faint oak, roasted malt, and cranberry/dark fruit.

On draught at the Blue Nile for Als 40th June 28th. The beer was opaque black with thick creamy brown/tan head. In the aroma there was oak, subtle cranberries, and roasted malt. In the flavor there was a lot of oak, some tart cranberries, and subtle roasted malt. The beer was smooth with a tart cranberry/oaky finish. As it warmed it got even more oaky.

[Tap] at Pigfoots 40th birthday party at the Blue Nile. Pours deep, deep brown with a medium tan head of fairly fine bubbles. Aroma is a little tart, malty but difficult to nail down a base style. Not a whole lot of hops in the nose, but the cranberries really come through, especially as it warms. Flavor is a bit sweet and malty, with the cranberries really coming through towards the middle and end. Somewhat of a lasting tartness from the cranberries. The biggest disappointment was the thin mouthfeel, but otherwise a decent beer.

Bottle shared with Doc, Not to be rude: Pours a very deep brown with a thin white head. Aroma is of tart cranberry and an undertone of cranberry. Taste is tart with cranberry, with slight tastes or carmel and choclate. Finish is very tart.

In short: Simplistic syrupy black ale of some kind
How: Tap at Clark Street Ale House (Chicago)
The look: Black body toped by a small beige ring of foam
In long: A big syrupy.  The truckload of cranberries and black roasted malts turn into a sticky black liquorice flavour.  So much so that the cranberries were not even the dominant flavour.  Mainly I had an overall impression of a fruity tar.  No complexity, not subtlety.  Where are the hops?  Finish is burnt rubber.  Just a big brutal syrupy beer.   Surly Two much for its own good.

On tap:  Black in color with almost no head though there is a bunch of extremely fine bubbles when swirled.  Aromas were of semi-sweet chocolate, roasted malt, tart red fruit and vanilla.  In the mouth the cranberries really show themselves along with the roasted malt.  The palate is very well-balanced with good weight and wondeful acidity, likely due to the abundance of cranberries.  A very nice transition beer from the heavy winter beers to the crisp summer ones on the way.

pour is opaque black with a nonexistant tan head....smell is lightly tart but sweet with cocoa still....nice chocolate covered cherry flavor (I didnt know it was cranberry until after the fact)....tart and sweet with a nice bittersweet cocoa finish

From the tap and served in a snifter:  Good looking, a deep mahogany body with a dense tan head that hung around for the duration.  The aroma was tart with a fruitiness that I didnt readily identify as cranberry (although I drink the juice at least once a day), had some roasty malts, and a woody/fruit stone bitterness.  The bitterness intensified somewhat during the drinking, but so did the fruity funkiness and now smoky malt flavors.  It finished on a bitter, sour note, somewhat dry.  Good stuff.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Brewing Company, Villa Park, IL<font size=-1>

On tap at Clark Street.  Pours black with spotty tan head and nice lacing.  Smell is odd and doesnt seem to mesh well between the fruitiness and roastiness.  Somewhat tart and strange from the cranberries.  Taste is roasty and fruity with a medium body and light carbonation, but for some reason the sourness of the fruit didnt seem to work with the roasty malt to my liking.

@ Arborfest, draft

Dry cranberry aroma, dark brown and opaque color.  Sour on the tongue.  Definitely taste the cranberries, but not overwhelmed.  Good brew, although not to my liking.

At the Maproom. Fruit and chocolate sharpness in the aroma. Plum, perfume, cream, sweet cigar tobacco, and peach scents. The aroma becomes quite sweet upon multiple sniffs. I do smell the cranberries, but I dont necessarily smell them as cranberries. Pours an opaque dark brown with a moderate to large amount of peach-tan head. The head is soft in both color and texture, and it contains large bubbles. Produces pleasant, extensive lacing. The initial taste comes as an overwhelming but delicious cranberry explosion. Its like unsweetened, concentrated cranberry juice, slightly sour and remarkably tart and tangy. Not my kinda beer!

On tap at the Maproom.  Pours dark brown-black with a small beige head.  Aromas of yeast, tart fruits and sweet malts.  Chocolate and roasted malts peek out as it warms but they are secondary for this fruit beer.  Flavors are tart and dry at first.  This turns to toffee and cranberry with a dry chocolate finish. More of the chocolate rises with warmth.  All around though, this is a strange one.

draft at sheffields...... poured a dark cloudy caramel brown with a decent sized light brown head.... aroma made up of sour tart red fruit and some oak qualities to boot.  i dont think this was aged in barrels but i did get a sense of that in the nose and also the flavor....flavors had red fruit, cranberries with a little barrel age influence it seems. some sour tart fruit on top of it all but it all ends right there.  there was just something missing from this.  i wish the flavors were a little more assertive and long lasting.

On tap at Small Bar.  Poured a thick, deep red with a creamy cap of beige head.  The aroma was quite awesome, sporting spicy/tart cranberry notes paired with sweeter chocolates and a bit of coffee.. the final impression left rich, deep fruits along with dry herbal overtones.. this came together very well.  Deep cranberry skin tartness hit the tongue first and laced its was through the drink.. chocolate, cranberry meat, and light oak fill out the middle.. spicy herbs and tart cranberries return for the long, warm finish.. I found this a good kind of unique.  Tart and fuller-bodied on the palate with very good balance.. creamy carbonation and a warm hit on the back.. great beer!

What another amazing concoction from Surly.  This had the flavor of cranberries and coffee.  How does that taste good you ask?  Well you add in some oak and vanilla, and god know =s what else.  It is mellow and craftful.  I was very happy to be in the right place at the right time for this one.

On tap. Pours a deep brown/red with a tall whitish head. The aroma is thick and cheesy. I get lots of creamy cheese scents, sour cream, vanilla, even a dash of bourbon. The flavor is oaky and tart all around with a grape-like quality. This is just sour enough to make things internesting. I actually really liked this one, despite my hatred for cranberries.

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2008 Rating 100.... on tap at Maproom. Nice thick black popur with creamy tannish head. Aromas of toasty coconut emerge as the beer warms, slight metallic (iron?) aromas, atouch of sour and old coffee. The sharp cranberry tart flavor hits me first, throwing me for a little bit of a loop. The tartness is followed by some minor chocolate, some farely significant oaky notes (was this barrel aged at all?) Finishes with some pleasent hop bitterness and dry oak feeling. Body is pretty creamy and finishes on the drier side. This is a very strange and delicious beer. Glad to have been able to try this one for sure.

on tap at the maproom. pours dark brown with whispy tan head. nose of chocolate covered cranberries. flavor is initially sweet but almost instantly becomes sour for a brief moment, then the very dry fruit and chocolate notes come forward leaving a bland dry cranberry and bakers chocolate presence on the palate. pretty straight forward and bland to me. looks like the locals liked this one a lot more.

I dont know what to think about this guy, its sort of mysterious.  At first I was not a fan - too sharp with the cran.  Maybe it got better and smoother as it warmed or i just warmed up to it.  Sour stout, new for me and im glad I tried it, although I dont think i would order again.  Well crafted, but its one of those beers you ask, its neat that you COULD brew it, but SHOULD you brew it?  Sounds like its just not my thing.
Deep, dark brown color with just a wisp of a head.  Fruity aroma.  Definitely cranberries with a little cherry.  The taste is heavily malty and a little sour/tart cranberry.  Feels almost chewy.

Very dark brown and almost free of carbonation.  Fruit and malt aroma, but the malt is dry rather than thick.  This beer is fairly dry overall.  Flavor has good, sour fruit, and it does seem like natural fruit and no artificial flavoring.  Not sweet at all, but interesting palate that is kind of heavy.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2008 On tap at the Blue Nile.  Drew a dark brownish-black with a thick brownish-grey head.  Aroma is sweet, with a distinct syrupy hops scent complemented by hints of chocolate, caramel, and the slightest bit of roasted malt.  Taste is extremely creamy and medium-bodied, with a totally unexpected fruit flavor -- apricot, grapefruit, and a bit of cranberry -- thats initially bewildering, then mellow, then ends a little astringently.  A little one-dimensional in terms of flavor, but amazingly executed -- a delicious offering.

Pours a very dark, opaque amber red with a close to no head. what is there is just tan lacing. flavor is definite fruit flavors, which is the first to come through. Odd coffee undertones. I believe it is the bitterness mixed with the malts.... notes of raspberry and cranberry. Flavor is a definite TARTNESS. body is light, perhaps surprisingly so because of the overall appearance of it. Based on its darkness one would expect it to be darker.

On tap in a dark bar - appearance appears to be dark in color with a deep ruby streak. Head is minimal. Flavor is tart - fizzy cranberry juice with a sweet malt backbone. Cranberries are obvious but dont overwhelm. I may be getting some hops toward the end, but its hard to tell with the cranberries providing most of the bitterness. Some port wine and chocolate in here as well. Somewhat fizzy and medium bodied. Well made beer - definitely different. Improves as it warms. Not a session beer, though.

(Draught)  Pours a murky dark brown body with a small beige head.  Aroma of toasted marshmallow, cranberry, and toffee.  Flavor of cranberry, rye bread, molasses, cocoa, and roasted malt with a dry finish from the cranberry.

On tap at Busters, served in tulip glass.  Dark brown-black body with thin off-white head.  Solid, medium body and mouthfeel.  Not much flavor initially on the palate, but builds into strong grapefruit and cranberry flavors.  Finishes tart with bitter grapefruit aftertaste.  More citrus and malt tones come out as it warms.

Winterfest 2008 
Nice aroma.  No doubt there are many cranberries in this as that is the dominant smell.  Im normally not a huge fruit beer guy, but this was good and interesting.  Beneath the cranberry, there are some roasted notes as well as molasses.  A tart finish.  Not much on the hops.  Alcohol is well hidden.  Overall a nice dessert type beer with the sweet and tart complimenting each other well.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2008 Tap at the Blue Nile served in a Tripel Karmeleit glass.Served cold and at first was rather unimpressed but as the beer warms it takes on much more depth.   Plenty of tart cranberry and roasted malt on the nose. Creamy malt - vanilla, cocoa, oatmeal and alcohol. Pours a dark, thick amber/brown with a thin off white head leaving spotty lacing. Tart and bitter cranberry on the tongue. An odd but wildly intriguing beer. Dry oaky malt and tart fruit. A hint of citrus hops. Creamy, mostly full bodied with a lasting tart finish. Excellent now but I cant wait to revisit.

On tap at Cafe 28 on 2/3/2008.  I really did not think they had it as I drove over for Super Bowl Sunday brunch.  However, when I got there, it was on the menu and I asked the cute waitress if it was really on.  She smiled big and said it was - and that it was good (with an evil eye).  Served in a Darkness snifter, it has a dark brown red appearance and a nice and sustaining off white to tan head that laces all the way down.  The aroma is more focused on the roasted malt, with some fruity notes.  The flavor starts out all stout like chocolate and roasty, but then out of nowhere the cranberries slam in your face.  It really suprises you as it reveals the fruit late.  Almost like a dark and malty fruit lambic or farmhouse due to the tartness.  Awesome smooth palate.  Yep, good!

Tried this at Grumpys NE for their 10th anniversary.  Poured a nice deep reddish color with a tint of brown.  Nose was pretty sweet with a good dose of tart cranberry, dark fruits, sweet roasted malt and a hint of chocolate.  Very sweet on the palate, but not overdone, with a good dose of ripe red and dark fruits accompanying the cranberry, chocolate, sweet roasted malt, and brown sugar accenting the tart cranberry character.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: On draught at the Blue Nile during the Surly Two special early release party. Pours an opaque dark reddish brown brew with a thick and lumpy tan head that has excellent retention and sticky lacing. Aroma of roasted dark malt, dark pitted fruit, sour hops, dark chocolate, molasses and some tart cranberries. Taste is thick, full bodied, with flavors of sour dark malt, cranberries, dark chocolate and a touch of raspberries. Finish is tart and mildly bitter along with a dark roasted malt and cranberry aftertaste. Uff Dah! This brew reminds me of Surly Cranberry One, but much thicker in texture and taste.

Appearance: Reddish black, with a dependable, sturdy cocoa head. Looks every bit the part for a cranberry stout.

Aroma is tart fruit, slightly sour, slightly sweet, ultimately dry, and very likable.

Taste: the tart grips the tongue first, snappy, fresh, fully flavored, and other elements lie underneath. Solid malt, abundant cocoa, dark malts in unfailing supply, but the cranberry flavor keeps bobbing on top and dominates the taste. Alternately sweet and sour, and then dry, still some roast felt below the fruit, making for a satisfying drink. Youve got to love the fruit, though, if you dont, its not for you.

Alcohol is barely evident, and despite being a hearty, full-bodied ale, the fruit aspect helps make this surprisingly refreshing. Easy to drink, but one to pause and ponder with...Id dig this if anyone made it, but its extra cool as an anniversary one shot from our local bad boys
...relax and enjoy...reflect on two years of great beer...happy 2nd, Surly! May you prosper through many more!

On tap at the Nile. Dark dark brown with a large tan head that recedes fairly quick. Light but nice aroma of cranberry, some chocolate. Nice sweetness, finishes with a little tartness. Alcohol is very well hidden. Beautiful mouth feel. 
copyright grimreeser

(on tap at the Blue Nile) Pours black with a large tan head that never leaves.  Nice aroma of cranberry, cocoa, and some nice hops as well.  Taste is just amazing with a great balance between the chocolate and light roast flavors, and the tartness from the cranberry.  This mixture just dances on the tongue.  The finish is also remarkable with a lingering tartness with the cranberry as well as just a slight bitterness from the hops.  Full mouthfeel and perfectly carbonated.  Wow, this is one great beer.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2008 [On-Tap] Pours black with a big tan head. Aroma is cranberry, chocolate, almost a light citrusy orange at times. Taste is cranberry, chocolate and light roasted malt. There is a little bitterness from the cranberry in there too, which is to be expected. Medium mouthfeel, long cranberry chocolate and malt finish. Smooth. Wow, what a beer. Amazingly unique and the flavors blend together so well. I was really, really impressed by this beer. Re-Rate: 9-5-9-4-18=4.5Re-Rate: After loving this beer the first time and then seeing some of the ratings that followed, I was left wondering if I had just gotten an exceptional keg or what. I have had it again and I liked it nearly as much. The palate was a bit thinner than I remembered it as being, but otherwise it was still an outstanding, unique beer.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2016 Original rating, 1-25-08: Approximately 10 oz. pour on tap at Blue Nile in Minneapolis at the official release on 1-23-08. Poured into a Maredsous glass. Fruit and chocolate sharpness in the aroma. Plum, perfume, cream, sweet cigar tobacco, and peach scents. The aroma becomes quite sweet upon multiple sniffs. I do smell the cranberries, but I dont necessarily smell them as cranberries. Pours an opaque dark brown with a moderate to large amount of peach-tan head. The head is soft in both color and texture, and it contains large bubbles. Produces pleasant, extensive lacing. The initial taste comes as an overwhelming but delicious cranberry explosion. Its like unsweetened, concentrated cranberry juice, slightly sour and remarkably tart and tangy. The underlying beer seems to be a stout with dark chocolate and light coffee flavors. The stout flavors emerge only upon multiple sips, after the initial cranberry shock subsides somewhat. Its almost like two beers in one: First, its a New Glarus-like hardcore fruit beer (think Belgian Red or Raspberry Tart but with cranberries). Its not quite as fruit-intense as New Glarus legendary brews, but its pretty close. Second, its a cranberry-tinged strong stout. Interesting, dry, earthy aftertaste that is hard to describe. Medium to heavy body. Smooth and soft in the palate. Surly two is a complex, uncompromising, delicious beer. It may be my second-favorite Surly product, behind only Darkness. 8/4/9/4/17. Re-rate, 3-20-16: Re-brewed version. 4 oz. pour, on tap at Surly Beer Hall in Minneapolis, Minnesota. Consumed on 3-12-16. Pours an opaque, dark brown with an almost purple hue (actually an amber hue toward the end). Large amount of medium-lasting, taupe head. Good, thick, extensive lacing. I love the color and head. Its hard for a beer to look better, except that the head could last longer. Dark-chocolate-covered raisin scent. Really lovely, roasted maltiness in the aroma. Scents of cranberry in the form of craisin as well as chocolate. Smells great. Flavor features dark chocolate with a tart, cranberry bite. Roasted dryness and delicious, tart, cranberry finish. Dusty. Fresh cranberry as well as cranberry sauce. Orange. Full body. Smooth and almost oily in the palate. Lively. Very good palate effects. Excellent, much as I remembered it. This beer was ahead of its time. Im so glad to get another taste. Delicious! 8/4/9/4/17. Combined rating: 8/4/9/4/17

On tap at the Nile. Dark dark brown with a large tan head that recedes fairly quick. Light but nice aroma of cranberry, some chocolate. Nice sweetness, finishes with a little tartness. Alcohol is very well hidden. Beautiful mouth feel.

Tap at the Nile.  Pretty tart, but not overally sweet, which was nice. Slightly hoppy afterbite. Doesnt seem like a 9% brew at all. Very smooth, and the cran dominates all, and I found it to be on the same vane as the NG Belgian Red and Rasp. Tart. Not bad company to be in. awesome

mmmmmmmmm. this is good. tap at the nile on the 24th. great deep color with hues of red mixed in. ultra creamy head that laces like a champ. starts very smooth, but very complex as well. slight sweetness up front but fades very quickly to tart, sourness, but not overly so. i was a big fan. some subdued hoppiness towards the back side, but dont last long once the tartness from the cranberry attacks the palate and hangs on for a while. great beer. excellent sipper. Would be great with fat steak and baked taters!!

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2008 Had this on tap at the Blue Nile.  Very rich dark brown color with a nice two finger thick light brown head.  Chocolate as well as dark fruit on the aroma.  A bit of citrus hops in flavor but very faint.  There is a definite dark fruit flavor here that I cannot quite pinpoint, but it lingers a while after.  Nice complex brew.

Tap Blue Nile- My second beer release at the Nile. Great place and nice to be able to spend time with Todd. Really nice guy. 
Apperance reminds me of Surly One- quite dark with a cocoa head. Smell is of dark fruit. Wow- I just got smacked in the head with a cranberry. The palate is ultra silky smooth and goes down like velvet....but....I....just....cant....get...past. I let it warm for a while and still felt that the intense tartness of the cranberry dominated. I tried to think of it as a super hoppy beer where the malt is overshadowed, but I didnt work. A bit too much tartness for me. Long live Surly!

Pours with a huge creamy light brown head, dark red muddy body.  The head reminded me of hot cocoa.  Aromas of spruce and grapefruit, later aromas of cranberry became much more prevalent......medium body with an oily texture that I did not care for.  Flavor was impressive but does not translate to me necessarily liking it, cranberry at the start, tart in the middle and a hoppy ending.

a deep purrple brown color with faint head.  Dark fruits chocolate and cranberries on the nose with a little spice. Body was thick and chewy with sweet malts a wonderful sourness and a cranberry bite at the end.

The Blue Nile may have run outta traditional serving glasses while trying to get everyone in the place a glass of this wonderful brew but the Blue Moon pilsner glass I got will do just fine. Pours a deep brown/black with a slight purple hint when held up to the light. Nice fairly thick foamy brownish head sits atop the beer and sticks to the walls of the glass as you drink it down coating them nicely. Smells of smooth malt with a hint of creaminess. The cranberries come through nicely and have a bit of a bitterness. Allowed to warm a bit, a nice bit of chocolate comes out. Mmmm. Very smooth and malty body with a medium carbonation. Hint of light caramel and chocolate in the distance. The cranberries are great. Sweetness that is shortly followed by a bit of bitterness and a touch of sourness. Alcohol isnt present in the taste and this one goes down very smooth. Some commented that they could drink only one glass but Ill be back for plenty more.

Tap at the Blue Nile.  Burgundy and oak hued pour.  Deliriously complex malt and fruit aroma.  Rich swaths of caramel, port and brown sugar smother the nose in front with a delicious alcoholic warmth.  Drying out quickly and getting tart with tannic berry skin.  Caramelized sugar on cashews and hazelnuts, with lots of cocoa dust; plenty of green leafiness, unripened mango and apple skin.  Salty, aged cheddar in a flash.  Really weird, intriguing, and altogether pleasant.  Flavor brings the rich, maple syrup, raisin, and honey with a juicy cranberry and black cherry coating to start; this tends to be very much like a fruity syrah or temporanillo in its bold, jammy tartness.  Hints of raw almond, cinnamon, lemon zested goat cheese, lavender, and the tart bitterness of an apple seed, layering a lighter sweetness over the original elements.  Brilliantly sour, earthy, and completely collected.  Palate is lucid, rounded, and medium to full in body; chocolatey, and very smooth.  Rich, with a butterscotch and molasses pulse at the finish, but finalizing with a great and simple tart quality.  Theres a lot of Cuvee de Tomme in this one, which was a lovely surprise; its a beautiful, expertly crafted beer.

Draught, release party at the Blue Nile, Minneapolis. Rich, malt aroma. Unique. Some hops. Really nice. Fully opaque body. Light brown head. Dishwater lace. Salty brew as to be expected from cranberries. Somewhat sour. Improves as it warms. The cranberry particles settle to the bottom and enhance the flavor as you reach the bottom of the glass. Perhaps not my favorite of Surlys brews, but a clearly quality effort within the style, showcasing Todd Haugs considerable talent as a brewer. You should seek this brew out as it is considerably different than any Surly brew youve had or likely will have for some time.
